text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
Specimen 0..*SpecimenSample for analysis
extension 1..*ExtensionExtension
Slices for extension Content/Rules for all slices
BiologicalSampleOrigin S1..1(Complex)The origin of the sample
URL: https://build.fhir.org/ig/arkhn/arkhn-ig-osiris/StructureDefinition/BiologicalSampleOrigin
Slices for value[x] Content/Rules for all slices
value[x]:valueCodeableConcept 1..1CodeableConceptThe origin of the sample
BasedOnCondition S0..1(Complex)Tumur Pathology Event concerned by the sample
URL: https://build.fhir.org/ig/arkhn/arkhn-ig-osiris/StructureDefinition/BasedOnCondition
Slices for value[x] Content/Rules for all slices
value[x]:valueReference 0..1Reference(Tumor Pathology Event)Value of extension
identifier S1..1IdentifierIdentifier of the biological sample
type S1..1CodeableConceptThe nature of the sample
Binding: Biological Sample Nature Value Set (preferred)
subject S0..1Reference(Oncology Patient)Where the specimen came from. This may be from patient(s), from a location (e.g., the source of an environmental sample), or a sampling of a substance or a device
parent S0..1Reference(Biological Sample)Identifier of the parent biological sample
collection
Slices for collected[x] 1..1dateTimeCollection time
Slice: Unordered, Open by type:$this
collected[x]:collectedDateTime S1..1dateTimeCollection date
quantity S0..1SimpleQuantityPercentage of tumor cells
value 0..1decimalNumerical value (with implicit precision)
unit 0..1stringUnit representation
Required Pattern: %
code 0..1codeCoded form of the unit
Required Pattern: C4055283
bodySite S1..1CodeableConceptTopography of the tumor sample
Binding: Topography Value Set (preferred)
condition S0..1CodeableConceptStorage method
Binding: Storage temperature Value Set (extensible)
text 0..1stringPlain text representation of the concept
Required Pattern: Storage temperature of the sample.

Documentation for this format

name: BiologicalSample
title: Biological Sample
description: Description of a biological sample coming from an oncology Patient, with its storage condition.

element.definition: A sample to be used for analysis.

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where((('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().as(canonical) | %resource.descendants().as(uri) | %resource.descendants().as(url))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()
constraint.xpath: not(exists(for $id in f:contained/*/f:id/@value return $contained[not(parent::*/descendant::f:reference/@value=concat('#', $contained/*/id/@value) or descendant::f:reference[@value='#'])]))

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: An Extension

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: Allows you to indicate the origin of the sample.

Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.definition: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
element.comment: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition SHALL be a URI for the Structure Definition defining the extension.

element.definition: Value of extension - must be one of a constrained set of the data types (see [Extensibility](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extensibility.html) for a list).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comment: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the HL7 v3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL NOT be used to infer meaning. Generally, at most only one of the coding values will be labeled as UserSelected = true.
element.requirements: Allows for alternative encodings within a code system, and translations to other code systems.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: CE/CNE/CWE subset one of the sets of component 1-3 or 4-6

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comment: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.short: Tumur Pathology Event concerned by the sample
element.definition: Tumur Pathology Event concerned by the sample.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.definition: Unique identifier of the sample within the health center (barcode, text identifier).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: CX / EI (occasionally, more often EI maps to a resource id or a URL)
II - The Identifier class is a little looser than the v3 type II because it allows URIs as well as registered OIDs or GUIDs.  Also maps to Role[classCode=IDENT]

element.definition: The identifier assigned by the lab when accessioning specimen(s). This is not necessarily the same as the specimen identifier, depending on local lab procedures.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: CX / EI (occasionally, more often EI maps to a resource id or a URL)
II - The Identifier class is a little looser than the v3 type II because it allows URIs as well as registered OIDs or GUIDs.  Also maps to Role[classCode=IDENT]

element.definition: The availability of the specimen.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labelled as a modifier because it is a status element that contains status entered-in-error which means that the resource should not be treated as valid

binding.description: Codes providing the status/availability of a specimen.

element.definition: Information indicating the nature of the sample.
element.comment: The type can change the way that a specimen is handled and drives what kind of analyses can properly be performed on the specimen. It is frequently used in diagnostic work flow decision making systems.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Where the specimen came from. This may be from patient(s), from a location (e.g., the source of an environmental sample), or a sampling of a substance or a device
element.definition: Where the specimen came from. This may be from patient(s), from a location (e.g., the source of an environmental sample), or a sampling of a substance or a device.
element.comment: References SHALL be a reference to an actual FHIR resource, and SHALL be resolveable (allowing for access control, temporary unavailability, etc.). Resolution can be either by retrieval from the URL, or, where applicable by resource type, by treating an absolute reference as a canonical URL and looking it up in a local registry/repository.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
SHALL have a contained resource if a local reference is provided

mapping.map: The target of a resource reference is a RIM entry point (Act, Role, or Entity)

element.short: The time when specimen was received for processing
element.definition: Time when specimen was received for processing or testing.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Identifier of the parent biological sample
element.definition: Unique identifier of the parent sample (barcode, text identifier). For example, an aliquot or a sample extracted from another sample (e.g. histological number).
element.comment: The parent specimen could be the source from which the current specimen is derived by some processing step (e.g. an aliquot or isolate or extracted nucleic acids from clinical samples) or one of many specimens that were combined to create a pooled sample.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
SHALL have a contained resource if a local reference is provided

mapping.map: The target of a resource reference is a RIM entry point (Act, Role, or Entity)

element.definition: Details concerning a service request that required a specimen to be collected.
element.comment: The request may be explicit or implied such with a ServiceRequest that requires a blood draw.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
SHALL have a contained resource if a local reference is provided

mapping.map: The target of a resource reference is a RIM entry point (Act, Role, or Entity)

element.definition: Details concerning the specimen collection.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.definition: Person who collected the specimen.
element.comment: References SHALL be a reference to an actual FHIR resource, and SHALL be resolveable (allowing for access control, temporary unavailability, etc.). Resolution can be either by retrieval from the URL, or, where applicable by resource type, by treating an absolute reference as a canonical URL and looking it up in a local registry/repository.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
SHALL have a contained resource if a local reference is provided

mapping.map: The target of a resource reference is a RIM entry point (Act, Role, or Entity)

element.definition: Time when specimen was collected from subject - the physiologically relevant time.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The date of sample collection.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: How long it took to collect specimen
element.definition: The span of time over which the collection of a specimen occurred.
element.comment: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for the comparator.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If a code for the unit is present, the system SHALL also be present
There SHALL be a code if there is a value and it SHALL be an expression of time.  If system is present, it SHALL be UCUM.

mapping.map: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values
PQ, IVL<PQ> depending on the values

element.definition: The percentage of tumor cells quantified in the tumor sample.
element.comment: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for the comparator.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If a code for the unit is present, the system SHALL also be present
The comparator is not used on a SimpleQuantity

mapping.map: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: The value of the measured amount. The value includes an implicit precision in the presentation of the value.
element.comment: The implicit precision in the value should always be honored. Monetary values have their own rules for handling precision (refer to standard accounting text books).
element.requirements: Precision is handled implicitly in almost all cases of measurement.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: PQ.value, CO.value, MO.value, IVL.high or IVL.low depending on the value

element.definition: Not allowed to be used in this context
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings SHALL NOT exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: Need a framework for handling measures where the value is <5ug/L or >400mg/L due to the limitations of measuring methodology.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

binding.description: How the Quantity should be understood and represented.

element.definition: A human-readable form of the unit.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings SHALL NOT exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: There are many representations for units of measure and in many contexts, particular representations are fixed and required. I.e. mcg for micrograms.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: System that defines coded unit form
element.definition: The identification of the system that provides the coded form of the unit.
element.comment: see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_resource_identifier
element.requirements: Need to know the system that defines the coded form of the unit.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A computer processable form of the unit in some unit representation system.
element.comment: The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.  The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system.
element.requirements: Need a computable form of the unit that is fixed across all forms. UCUM provides this for quantities, but SNOMED CT provides many units of interest.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A coded value specifying the technique that is used to perform the procedure.
element.comment: Not all terminology uses fit this general pattern. In some cases, models should not use CodeableConcept and use Coding directly and provide their own structure for managing text, codings, translations and the relationship between elements and pre- and post-coordination.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The  technique that is used to perform the procedure.

element.definition: Anatomical location of the tumor specimen according to the International Classification of Diseases for Oncology.
element.comment: If the use case requires  BodySite to be handled as a separate resource instead of an inline coded element (e.g. to identify and track separately)  then use the standard extension [bodySite](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-bodysite.html).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Whether or how long patient abstained from food and/or drink
element.definition: Abstinence or reduction from some or all food, drink, or both, for a period of time prior to sample collection.
element.comment: Representing fasting status using this element is preferred to representing it with an observation using a 'pre-coordinated code'  such as  LOINC 2005-7 (Calcium [Moles/​time] in 2 hour Urine --12 hours fasting), or  using  a component observation ` such as `Observation.component code`  = LOINC 49541-6 (Fasting status - Reported).
element.requirements: Many diagnostic tests require fasting  to facilitate accurate interpretation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Codes describing the fasting status of the patient.

element.definition: Details concerning processing and processing steps for the specimen.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Textual description of procedure.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings SHALL NOT exceed 1MB in size

element.short: Indicates the treatment step  applied to the specimen
element.definition: A coded value specifying the procedure used to process the specimen.
element.comment: Not all terminology uses fit this general pattern. In some cases, models should not use CodeableConcept and use Coding directly and provide their own structure for managing text, codings, translations and the relationship between elements and pre- and post-coordination.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Type indicating the technique used to process the specimen.

element.short: Material used in the processing step
element.definition: Material used in the processing step.

Resolution can be either by retrieval from the URL, or, where applicable by resource type, by treating an absolute reference as a canonical URL and looking it up in a local registry/repository.

mapping.map: The target of a resource reference is a RIM entry point (Act, Role, or Entity)

element.short: Date and time of specimen processing
element.definition: A record of the time or period when the specimen processing occurred.  For example the time of sample fixation or the period of time the sample was in formalin.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The container holding the specimen.  The recursive nature of containers; i.e. blood in tube in tray in rack is not addressed here.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.definition: Id for container. There may be multiple; a manufacturer's bar code, lab assigned identifier, etc. The container ID may differ from the specimen id in some circumstances.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: CX / EI (occasionally, more often EI maps to a resource id or a URL)
II - The Identifier class is a little looser than the v3 type II because it allows URIs as well as registered OIDs or GUIDs.  Also maps to Role[classCode=IDENT]

element.definition: Textual description of the container.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings SHALL NOT exceed 1MB in size

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Kind of container directly associated with specimen
element.definition: The type of container associated with the specimen (e.g. slide, aliquot, etc.).
element.comment: Not all terminology uses fit this general pattern. In some cases, models should not use CodeableConcept and use Coding directly and provide their own structure for managing text, codings, translations and the relationship between elements and pre- and post-coordination.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The capacity (volume or other measure) the container may contain.
element.comment: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for the comparator.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If a code for the unit is present, the system SHALL also be present
The comparator is not used on a SimpleQuantity

mapping.map: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values
one of: SAC 16, SAC17 and SAC 20, or SAC 21 and SAC 20

element.definition: The quantity of specimen in the container; may be volume, dimensions, or other appropriate measurements, depending on the specimen type.
element.comment: The context of use may frequently define what kind of quantity this is and therefore what kind of units can be used. The context of use may also restrict the values for the comparator.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
If a code for the unit is present, the system SHALL also be present
The comparator is not used on a SimpleQuantity

mapping.map: PQ, IVL<PQ>, MO, CO, depending on the values

element.definition: Introduced substance to preserve, maintain or enhance the specimen. Examples: Formalin, Citrate, EDTA.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The storage temperature of the sample.
element.comment: Specimen condition is an observation made about the specimen.  It's a point-in-time assessment.  It can be used to assess its quality or appropriateness for a specific test.
element.requirements: The specimen condition can be used to assess its quality or appropriateness for a specific test.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comment: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the HL7 v3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL NOT be used to infer meaning. Generally, at most only one of the coding values will be labeled as UserSelected = true.
element.requirements: Allows for alternative encodings within a code system, and translations to other code systems.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: CE/CNE/CWE subset one of the sets of component 1-3 or 4-6

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comment: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.definition: To communicate any details or issues about the specimen or during the specimen collection. (for example: broken vial, sent with patient, frozen).
element.comment: For systems that do not have structured annotations, they can simply communicate a single annotation with no author or time.  This element may need to be included in narrative because of the potential for modifying information.  *Annotations SHOULD NOT* be used to communicate "modifying" information that could be computable. (This is a SHOULD because enforcing user behavior is nearly impossible).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Allows you to indicate the origin of the sample.

element.short: Tumur Pathology Event concerned by the sample
element.definition: Tumur Pathology Event concerned by the sample.
Unique identifier of the sample within the health center (barcode, text identifier).
Information indicating the nature of the sample.

element.short: Identifier of the parent biological sample
element.definition: Unique identifier of the parent sample (barcode, text identifier). For example, an aliquot or a sample extracted from another sample (e.g. histological number).
The date of sample collection.
The percentage of tumor cells quantified in the tumor sample.
Anatomical location of the tumor specimen according to the International Classification of Diseases for Oncology.
The storage temperature of the sample.
